title: 107_hr2313
content: The Act titled "Crane Tithe Tax Act of 2001" repeals the taxation of corporations. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 repeals various tax provisions related to corporate income, alternative minimum tax for corporations, unrelated business income tax, accumulated earnings tax, personal holding company tax, alternative tax for certain mutual savings banks, and tax imposed on life insurance companies. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 repeals various tax provisions related to corporate income, alternative minimum tax for corporations, unrelated business income tax, accumulated earnings tax, personal holding company tax, alternative tax for certain mutual savings banks, tax imposed on life insurance companies, certain mutual insurance companies, other insurance companies, regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, and income of foreign. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 repeals tax provisions related to various entities such as regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, and income of foreign corporations connected with United States business. SEC. 3. 10 PERCENT INCOME TAX RATE FOR INDIVIDUALS. Section 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to impose a 10 percent income tax rate for individuals. A 10 percent income tax is imposed on individuals based on earned income exceeding the exemption amount, which is $10,000 adjusted for inflation annually. The tax exemption amount is adjusted annually for inflation, calculated based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year. This adjustment is determined by comparing the Consumer Price Index (CPI) for October of the current year to the CPI for October of 2000. The tax exemption amount is adjusted annually for inflation based on the percentage difference between the Consumer Price Index (CPI) for October of the current year and the CPI for October of 2000. The CPI is the last Consumer Price Index for all-urban consumers published by the Department of Labor. If the increase is not a multiple of $10, it will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. The term 'earned income' is defined as wages, salaries, and other employee compensation, with adjustments made for rounding to the nearest multiple of $10 if necessary. The term 'earned income' includes wages, salaries, net earnings from self-employment, and certain dividends related to personal services. The term 'earned income' includes wages, salaries, and certain dividends related to personal services, excluding pensions, annuities, and tips at the discretion of the service-recipient. The term 'earned income' includes wages, salaries, and certain dividends related to personal services, excluding pensions, annuities, and tips at the discretion of the service-recipient. Fringe benefits valued at employer cost are also considered earned income. SEC. 4. Amnesty for all prior tax liability states that no person will be liable for any tax, penalties, or interest for taxable years before January 1, 2000. There are exceptions for amounts paid before the enactment of the Act and taxes related to illegal activities violating laws. SEC. 5. Repeal of special deductions, credits, and exclusions from income for individuals. Chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by removing specific exclusions, deductions, and credits related to individual income tax liability. SEC. 6. Repeal of estate and gift taxes. Subtitle B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding estate, gift, and generation-skipping taxes is repealed. SEC. 7. Effective dates. The amendments made by this Act apply to taxable years after enactment. Repeal of estate and gift taxes applies to estates of decedents dying after enactment. The Secretary of the Treasury must submit technical changes to the Committee on Ways and Means within 90 days of enactment. The Treasury must submit technical changes to the Committee on Ways and Means within 90 days of enactment to reflect the changes in the Internal Revenue Code made by this Act.
